qas.question: What were the men and women sent to the eastern front against their will called?
Who sent deserters families to concentration camps?
Where were the freed soviet captives sent?
When did the liberation of Strasbourg take place?
On what date was Strasbourg taken by the Germans?
In what year were the Free French Forces established?
How many Malgre-nous were forced to join the German forces?
In what year were the first memorials for Malgre-nous built?
How many Malgre-nous were able to desert the Wehrmacht?

context: Many people from Strasbourg were incorporated in the German Army against their will, and were sent to the eastern front, those young men and women were called <a0_0>Malgré-nous<a0_0/>. Many tried to escape from the incorporation, join the French Resistance, or desert the Wehrmacht but many couldn't because they were running the risk of having their families sent to work or concentration camps by the <a1_0>Germans<a1_0/>. Many of these men, especially those who did not answer the call immediately, were pressured to "volunteer" for service with the SS, often by direct threats on their families. This threat obliged the majority of them to remain in the German army. After the war, the few that survived were often accused of being traitors or collaborationists, because this tough situation was not known in the rest of France, and they had to face the incomprehension of many. In July <b5_0>1944<b5_0/>, <b6_0><b8_0>1500<b8_0/><b6_0/> malgré-nous were released from Soviet captivity and sent to <a2_0>Algiers<a2_0/>, where they joined the Free French Forces. Nowadays history recognizes the suffering of those people, and museums, public discussions and memorials have been built to commemorate this terrible period of history of this part of Eastern France (Alsace and Moselle). Liberation of Strasbourg took place on <a3_0><b4_0>23 November <b7_0>1944<b7_0/><b4_0/><a3_0/>.
